content: The Act may be cited as the "Innovation for Tomorrow's Workforce Act" and includes provisions for an Innovation Fund. Section 114 of the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 is amended to include a grant program for innovative strategies to improve career and technical education and align workforce skills with labor market needs. Grants may be awarded for evidence-based innovations, including pay for success initiatives to enhance student outcomes. The grant program aims to enhance career and technical education outcomes by improving teacher effectiveness, facilitating student transitions to postsecondary education or employment, and integrating work-based learning into the curriculum. The grant program aims to enhance career and technical education outcomes by increasing the effective use of technology, supporting new models for integrating academic and apprenticeship content, developing innovative delivery models, and collaborating with industry to design courses. Design and implement courses aligned to labor market needs in new fields, integrating STEM fields with career and technical education, and supporting innovative approaches to redesign the high school experience for students. Strategies to improve career and technical education outcomes, support programs addressing employer needs and workforce shortages in education fields. To receive a grant for secondary school education workforce innovations, an eligible entity must show matching funds of at least 25% from public or private sources, which can be waived by the Secretary in certain cases. To receive a grant under this program, an eligible entity must submit an application identifying the responsible agency, ensuring matching funds are obtained, and describing the program. The eligible entity must describe how grant funds will benefit students, especially special populations, and how the program will be coordinated with other activities. Priority is given to applications serving low-income families, and geographic diversity is considered in grant awards. The Secretary shall award at least 25 percent of funds to eligible entities for career and technical education activities serving specific educational agencies, institutions of higher education, consortia, or partnerships. The grant funds awarded to eligible entities must be used in accordance with specific guidelines, and each recipient must undergo evaluation. The partnerships eligible for grants include those between educational service agencies or nonprofit organizations and local educational agencies or institutions of higher education, as well as partnerships between grant recipients and State educational agencies. The grant recipients must undergo independent evaluation and submit an annual report detailing fund usage and performance indicators. The annual report must include a quantitative analysis of students described in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, special populations, and career and technical education programs. This includes the involvement of a local educational agency, an educational service agency, or an area career and technical education school. The curr_chunk defines eligible entities for a project, including requirements for a consortium to qualify, which may involve various organizations or employers. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements for a consortium to lead an eligible entity for a project, including the definition of a pay for success initiative. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. The curr_chunk authorizes appropriations for carrying out the outlined requirements for a consortium to lead an eligible entity in a pay for success initiative. SEC. 3. OPEN EDUCATION RESOURCES. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 related to making instructional content widely available, including the use of open educational resources. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 amendments aim to make instructional content widely available, potentially utilizing open educational resources. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 amendments include provisions for supporting pay-for-success initiatives and work-based learning opportunities. SEC. 5 of the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 amendments focuses on providing work-based learning opportunities and apprenticeships, including employer-led training resulting in recognized credentials. SEC. 6 introduces joint demonstration projects. The amendments to the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 focus on evaluating the effectiveness of projects authorized under paragraph (7) and improving the quality of career and technical education programs. Additionally, joint demonstration projects are introduced to provide work-based learning opportunities and apprenticeships. The Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 is amended to allow joint projects between the Secretary and the Secretary of Labor for integrated career and technical education programs. SEC. 7. COMPETENCY-BASED EDUCATION. Amends the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 to expand opportunities for students to participate in competency-based education programs.
